content: P.L. 106-554, signed in December 2000, enacted H.R. 5658 for Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government Appropriations in 2001. Funding was provided for various government accounts, including the General Services Administration and the Executive Residence for White House transitions. The President signed a transportation appropriations bill that partially funds accounts for White House transitions. Various measures were considered before the enactment of the FY2001 Treasury and General Government appropriations. Key measures include H.R. 4871 and S. Key measures include H.R. 4871 (House bill), S. 2900 (Senate bill), H.R. 4516 / H.R. 4985 (Legislative Branch Appropriation), P.L. 106-346 (Transportation Appropriations), P.L. 106-275 (FY2001 Continuing Funding Resolution), P.L. 106-426, P.L. 106-520 (presidential transition funding), and P.L. 106-554 (Enacts H.R. 5658, Treasury and General Government appropriations). The Act P.L. 106-554 authorizes funding for the presidential transition and White House moving expenses. P.L. 106-554 funds accounts within Treasury, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and General Government for FY2001. P.L. 106-346 provides supplemental funding for certain accounts. The President must submit the Budget of the United States Government annually to Congress. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) submits the Budget of the United States Government annually to Congress. Congress establishes a concurrent resolution for the government's budget and allocates funding levels to subcommittees. The FY2001 allocations for Treasury and General Government appropriations are discussed in the report. The FY2001 allocations for Treasury and General Government appropriations fund various law enforcement organizations under the Department of the Treasury, including the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms, Customs Service, Secret Service, and others. Additionally, Treasury appropriations cover agencies like the Internal Revenue Service, Financial Management Service, and Bureau of the Public Debt. The U.S. Postal Service is mostly self-supporting. The U.S. Postal Service is self-supporting, with limited federal contributions for services like free postal service for the blind. Appropriations for the Executive Office of the President cover salaries, expenses, and operations of various agencies within the EOP. The Executive Office of the President (EOP) funds various organizations like the Council of Economic Advisers, National Security Council, and Office of Management and Budget. The Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP) distributes funding for drug control initiatives to other entities. Independent agencies funded through this appropriation include the Federal Election Commission, General Services Administration, and National Archives. The Treasury and General Government appropriation includes titles that set governmentwide restrictions and rules, such as prohibiting the use of funds for employing non-U.S. citizens, requiring drug-free workplaces, and authorizing defined actions. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2001 includes provisions for drug-free workplaces, travel expenses for federal employees' immediate family members, and a .22% across-the-board rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority. A .22% across-the-board rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations funds will affect all accounts in the Treasury and General Government appropriations. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) must report on the implementation of the rescission when the FY2002 budget is submitted. The rescission applies to all net positive discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations, including advance appropriations provided in earlier years. The Act mandates a 0.22% reduction in FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations. Advance appropriations from FY2000 or earlier are affected, while those for FY2002 and beyond are not. Emergency appropriations are also subject to the reduction, applied equally to all programs, projects, and activities. The Act mandates a 0.22% reduction in FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations. Agencies will be provided with their rescission amounts by account and must allocate the reduction on a pro-rata basis to every program, project, and activity. The OMB will provide agencies with their rescission amounts by account. Reductions must be allocated on a pro-rata basis to all programs, projects, and activities. Reductions are required to be made from discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations only. The FY2001 budget submission included a 0.38% rescission, with specific reductions reported by the Office of Management and Budget. The administration stated that each department had to achieve the 0.38% savings, with some flexibility to protect high-priority programs. Certain programs were exempt from the rescission provisions, but overall it was to be universally applied. The FY2001 Military Construction Appropriations Act exempts certain programs from the rescission provisions, affecting accounts covered by the Treasury/Postal Service measure. The pay date for federal civilian personnel will revert to the original scheduled date in FY2000, altering the funding level for FY2000.
